Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Transforming public engagement by ecosystem scientists from burden to benefit: The Research Ambassador Program
Award.AbstractNarration:
Solving environmental issues such as global climate change requires new ways to understand the biosphere, and for much greater engagement between ecosystem scientists and the public. However, the current academic system does not reward, and sometimes penalizes, such activities. Academic scientists only rarely connect to those who have little access to science (e.g., people in assisted living centers, urban youth, or incarcerated people).

A pilot study suggested that scientists who engage with scientifically unaware audiences can generate new ideas, implement research, communicate results, and inspire ecological understanding in ways they could not if they were restricted to academic interactions or worked only with traditional public audiences. This proposed project explores a high-risk/potential high- return approach to create a rigorous, creative, sustainable, and transformative program to change public outreach from burden to benefit.

Working with a team of professional evaluators, the PI will gather well-established and early career ecosystem ecologists as "Research Ambassadors" (RAs) to engage scientifically unaware audiences via lectures, research projects, and websites. They will: a) brainstorm with appropriate public audiences whose interests overlap with the RAs'; b) provide guidance on outreach activities; and c) evaluate effects on the scientists and their science, as well as the public audiences.

This is a first systematic effort to provide a sustainable outreach program for senior and junior ecosystem scientists and to understand the impacts of public engagement on them. The results for ecosystem science can extend to other fields of science in the future.

Research Ambassadors will create materials and projects for underserved public audiences that are often disproportionately weighted toward minorities. This work will set the stage for large numbers of scientists to understand that contact with these audiences can bring academic and societal rewards.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our objectives were to: 1) recruit and guide scientists to create and implement public engagement activities, targeting underserved public audiences; 2) evaluate the impact of these activities on the public audiences and on the scientists; and 3) generate a generalizable model for scientists and educators more efficiently and effectively carry out scientist-initiated public engagement with underserved public audiences. We recruited and guided ecologists from an R1 Research university to understand the values and rewards of carrying out public engagement of their own research. Our team established both generalized and "custom" public engagement opportunities in local community groups for these ecologists. We also applied evaluation tools to assess the impacts of these activities. 

We:  created training venues to help ecologists achieve the most useful level and vocabulary for public audiences; provided venues and public engagement opportunities that will create efficient and effective avenues for public engagement so that an academic ecologist can spend minimum time from research and university teaching activities; and developed an extensible model for public engagement by scientists. Over 100 scientists have been included in public engagement events, and these have produced more than 250 outreach events, mainly in Utah, Washington State, and in other states across the country. These events have involved "science-inattentive" public audiences (those who are unaware or hostile to science (e.g., policy-makers, faith-based groups), or who do not have access to science education (e.g., prisoners), community groups that are often overlooked in traditional formal and informal science education efforts. One of our foci was to bring ecology and environmental sciences to a particularly underserved public audience, incarcerated men and women in state prisons and jails. We built on the "Sustainability in Prisons Project" (SPP) that the PI co-founded in Washington State in 2005, and with an NSF Conference grant (2013-2015), the project leaders created the SPP Network, a group of ca. 25 prisons and academic institutions that bring science lectures and ecology/conservation projects to prisoners. Specifically, the PI started an "SPP node" in Utah (Draper State Prison and Salt Lake County Jail). To date, 24 environmental scientists have delivered lectures about their work to inmates, and 4 have participated in hands-on conservation projects. We also created links between ecologists and other public groups who tend to have little interest in science. With funding from the Athletics Department at the University of Utah, the PI created the "Sports 'n Science" program, to raise awareness of the science behind sports. Six posters were created that featured a prominent University of Utah sports figure (football player, basketball player, gymnastics person) with a prominent scientist (Chair of the Math, Biology, and Physics departments), which were distributed to over 50 middle school science classes. The team also created 30-second videos with both a sports figure and a scientist; these were shown at half-time of football games on the Jumbotron.  The PI worked with local faith-based groups and ecologists to connect ecological values (trees, birds) with religious scriptures and symbolism via sermons in places of worship and by creating guidebooks that describe the trees and birds of churchyards in Salt Lake City. These were distributed to congregation members. The PI and her team have written science communication papers and delivered talks and workshops at ecological meetings.
